channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: MERS Cases Rise in South Korea, Health Officials Say
item.description: The Health Ministry said 64 people had contracted Middle East respiratory syndrome, and five people had died from the disease.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Saudi Arabia Shoots Down Missile Fired From Yemen
item.description: The Saudis said the missile was fired by forces loyal to Yemen’s Houthi rebels. It was the first time Yemeni factions had used the weapon since the conflict began more than two months ago.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Get New York Times’ WhatsApp Alerts on Pope’s Latin America Trip
item.description: Subscribe to our new account on WhatsApp to receive updates on the pope’s trip to Latin America and how the leader of the Roman Catholic Church is received.
item.media:description: Pope Francis blessed a child in Rio de Janeiro in 2013.

item.title: Putin Urges Western Pressure on Ukraine in Peace Effort
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia called on the United States and Europe to pressure the Ukrainian government to comply with a cease-fire accord that was reached in February.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Spanish Tuna Fishing Melds to Japan’s Taste, Endangering a 3,000-Year-Old Technique
item.description: In response to fishing quotas and consumer demand, companies that run the almadraba are shifting to ranching to help fatten the tuna, rather than lifting and killing their catch.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Laura Leon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bluefin tuna were surrounded by fishing nets in an ancient technique known as almadraba, as the fishing season opened off southern Spain.

item.title: Surprising Saudi Rises as a Prince Among Princes
item.description: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, 29, has swiftly accumulated more power than any prince has ever held, and he has become one of Saudi Arabia’s most visible leaders.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Pope Francis’ Message of Healing to a Divided Bosnia
item.description: Pope Francis praised the progress Bosnia made since the bloody ethnic conflict of the 1990s and urged an end to the sectarian conflicts around the world.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Bosnians greeted Pope Francis on Saturday as he was driven to a stadium in Sarajevo where he said Mass before 65,000 people.

item.title: Young, Seeking Change Over Ideology, Power Right Wing in Poland
item.description: In the Polish presidential race, the incumbent tied to the party that governed Poland during eight years of prosperity was trounced by a conservative foe.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: Andrzej Duda, a conservative, celebrating his recent victory over the incumbent Bronislaw Komorowski for the Polish presidency.

item.title: 13 Dead After Quake Strikes Malaysian Peak
item.description: Rescuers recovered the bodies of 11 more climbers from Mount Kinabalu, Malaysia’s highest peak, on Saturday, a day after it was struck by a magnitude 5.9 earthquake.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Saudi Arabia Shoots Down Missile Fired From Yemen
item.description: The Saudis said the missile was fired by forces loyal to Yemen’s Houthi rebels. It was the first time Yemeni factions had used the weapon since the conflict began more than two months ago.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: 300 More Bodies Found in China Ship Disaster
item.description: China Central Television said investigators would begin examining the ship in an effort to determine the cause of the accident, one of Asia’s worst maritime disasters in decades.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Task for Obama at Group of 7 Is to Reinforce Stance Against Russia
item.description: With Russia claiming a diplomatic victory after Secretary of State John Kerry’s visit, the challenge for the Obama administration becomes making sure Euro-American solidarity continues.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alexey Nikolsky/Ria Novosti/Kremlin
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia claimed a meeting last month with Secretary of State John Kerry in Sochi as a diplomatic triumph, creating a challenge for President Obama.

item.title: The Secret History of SEAL Team 6: Quiet Killings and Blurred Lines
item.description: The unit best known for killing Osama bin Laden has been converted into a global manhunting machine with limited outside oversight.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI, NICHOLAS KULISH, CHRISTOPHER DREW, SERGE F. KOVALESKI, SEAN D. NAYLOR and JOHN ISMAY
item.media:description: Navy SEAL operators awaited a night mission to capture insurgent leaders near Falluja, Iraq, in July 2007.

item.title: Taliban Overrun Remote District in Northeastern Afghanistan
item.description: Taliban fighters overwhelmed security forces in the Yamgan district of Badakhshan Province, where the government’s influence has waned considerably over the past two years.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

item.title: South Korea Reports Nine New Cases in MERS Virus Outbreak
item.description: Five of the new cases announced Saturday stemmed from transmissions at Samsung Medical Center in Seoul, one of the country’s best hospitals.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Train passengers wore protective masks in Seoul, South Korea, on Friday. The outbreak of Middle East respiratory syndrome was traced to Pyeongtaek, about 35 miles south of the capital.

item.title: Leonid Plyushch, Ukrainian Mathematician and Soviet Dissident, Dies
item.description: Mr. Plyushch, a Ukrainian mathematician, became a leading political dissident, prompting the Kremlin to commit him to a mental asylum for a nightmarish three years of drugs and deprivation.
item.dc:creator: DAVID STOUT

item.title: Israel’s Allies in U.S. Challenge Boycott
item.description: Israel’s advocates in the United States, mirroring the reaction among many in Israel, are scrambling to respond to the pro-Palestinian economic and disinvestment campaign.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A sign in Bethlehem, in the West Bank, calls for a boycott of products from Israeli settlements in the occupied territories.

item.title: U.S. Was Warned of System Open to Cyberattacks
item.description: The same attackers who breached the records of millions of government workers appear to be behind similar thefts at Anthem and Premera Blue Cross, cybersecurity experts say.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER, JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and NICOLE PERLROTH
item.media:description: Millions of records for American workers were stolen from the Office of Personnel Management in Washington by hackers.

item.title: Days Before Election in Turkey, Blasts at Rally Kill 2
item.description: The explosions, which wounded more than 100, took place at a huge opposition political rally in a predominantly Kurdish city.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: A protest on Friday after two explosions at a campaign rally for the opposition People’s Democratic Party in Diyarbakir. More than 100 were wounded; the cause has not been determined.

item.title: More Bodies Are Found as Yangtze Ship Is Lifted
item.description: With no hope of finding survivors in the submerged hull of a cruise ship that capsized this week with 456 people aboard, officials turned their attention on Friday to recovering the dead.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: The Oriental Star was lifted on Friday from the Yangtze River in China, four days after it capsized during a heavy storm.
